question.title: Showing a Java app by name and icon in Windows Task Manager
question.body:
I have a Java app and when running if I open Windows Task Manager, it is listed as "Open JDK Binary". Aside from not being informative, this is confusing if there are multiple Java apps running and you are trying to identify the correct to kill the process.

It would nice if I could have this listed with the app's name and icon. Does anyone know how to achieve this?

The app is typically run via java -jar myApp.jar.

question_comments.body: A simple fix is to define a different system property value for first argument to each launcher. eg  `java -Dmyapp=HELLO". This will visible to command line shown in Task Manager or "ps -ef | grep java | grep myapp=HELLO"

Cannot reproduce on Windows 11. Created an application image with --name DemoApp and it appears in the task manager as "DemoApp" (though oddly it would show the entire description if I set the --description argument; that seems like a possible bug).

I use jpackage and have the "--name" argument set and although it lists the app in Windows app menu [using the name specified in "--name"], it does not use this name in Task Manager and again shows it as "OpenJDK Platform Binary".

The only solution I could find is to package your Java application as a exe and set its name. That's something the answers to the duplicate suggest. So, as Mark said, not much has changed over the years except for new tools coming out (and old tools no longer being maintained). I've linked documentation for jpackage in a comment under the (currently) accepted answer of the duplicate.
Also, you may want to familiarize yourself a bit more with how Stack Overflow works. Questions are never automatically closed, but always in response to user or moderator action.

I closed your question, and that question is still relevant because nothing much has changed in this regard, except availability of tooling like jpackage being part of the JDK instead of requiring you to use external tooling. The fact a question is old does not make it less relevant, and if answers are outdated, add a bounty to it to get a more up-to-date answer.

My question was automatically closed. The reason given was that it was a duplicate of an answer that is 15 years old !! As though there is not the possibility of a better answer and solution within this time frame. Maybe there is someone out there who could have answered this question in the light that Java has moved from 4 to 24 in this span.
